head.title: How to Break Our Oil Dependence

hedline.hl1: How to Break Our Oil Dependence

block.p: Gov. Brian Schweitzer of Montana (''The Other Black Gold,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 3) and David Bodanis (''Gas Lite,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 3), in their suggestions to rid the United States of its oil dependence, do not mention the most obvious route: Build dense, transit-oriented and pedestrian-friendly communities.

Gov. Brian Schweitzer of Montana (''The Other Black Gold,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 3) and David Bodanis (''Gas Lite,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 3), in their suggestions to rid the United States of its oil dependence, do not mention the most obvious route: Build dense, transit-oriented and pedestrian-friendly communities.

Such communities drastically reduce the need for automobile use by taking advantage of so-called alternative forms of transportation, which pollute less and cost significantly less than personal auto use.
Also, they provide mobility to the sizable portion of the population that is too old, too young, too poor or disabled to drive a car.
High-density development also uses significantly less energy than single-family detached housing, which lowers overall energy demand.

No matter what carbon-based fuel you put in a car or a power plant, that fuel will run out someday. Why can't Americans see that the wasteful age of the detached house and the private auto is past its peak?
